properties.name: Allegheny Storage
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga w. allegheny avenue and 17th street philadelphia, paA plain looking warehouse from the exterior, the inside of this building holds one of the most extensive and bizarre collections. Filled with everything from hospital gurneys to a full size house facade, the Allegheny Storage facility is fascinating spot. To enter, walk half a block west on Allegheny until slightly past the facility, walk through the fence and to the north side of the building. Go through the door. Be careful of aggressive squatters and severe structural damage.

properties.name: Bartram Auto Garage
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 1600 S. 49th Street Philadelphia, PA Easily accessed, this abandoned auto garage can be seen from the street. It contains three structures, which all have been painted in graffiti. To enter, simply walk in from the street, be careful of structural damage when above the first floor, and watch for aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Bartram Pier
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 4900 Botanic Avenue Philadelphia, PAAn abandoned Pier located on the Schuylkill River. This also includes an interesting abandoned section of land with various large craters and other bizarre features. To enter, find where the fence opens and walk in. Be careful of structural damage to the pier, and aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Bartram Train Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 1612 S. 49th Street Philadelphia, PAHalf a rotating draw bridge used for trains, this bridge stands over the Schuylkill River. A Beautiful place to watch the river, and relatively safe and accessible. To enter, go north on 49th until you hit the train tracks, follow them to the Grays Ferry Bridge underpass, go to south to the river, and walk back west. Climb down the ladder at the bridge\'s end to find an interesting home.

properties.name: Beury Bank
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 3701 N. Broad Street Philadelphia, PAA one time prominent bank in North Philadelphia, this bank remains in fairly good condition on the lower floors. It has subway access, and the view from the roof is magnificent. The floors still have rooms and some still have furniture. To enter, climb up the scaffolding on the west side of the building, go through the window. This building is watched by Allied Barton Security, who will call the police if they see you. The upper floors are severely damaged and dangerous, and there are multiple signs of squatters. Flashlight necessary below the second floor.

properties.name: Boiler Building
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 4900 Grays Ave Philadelphia, PA A simple red brick building, with a fascinating interior. Was formerly used to boil water for trains passing by. East of it remains another building filled odd waste. To enter, walk south on 49th street until the chain link fence. Find the hole in the fence, and walk through, cross the tracks and walk one hundred feet east. Go to the south side of the building, climb up through the hole. Be careful of structural damage and aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Cambria House
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 1700 W. Cambria Street Philadelphia, PAAn oddly designed and small building, it ranges from a larger industrial part to a possibly residential section in the east section. Though the industrial piece is largely in ruins, the residential piece is still in good condition, and remains fairly interesting. To enter, walk through the West wall, or through the door located on the North face of the building. Watch for extreme structural damage and aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Divine Lorraine Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga N. Borad Street and Fairmount Avenue Philadelphia, PA USAThe first integrated hotel of it\'s kind, this nationally known historic landmark was once owned by the infamous Divine Family Cult. Today, the buildings once lavish rooms have been torn out, leaving nothing but open floor space except for the first floor, which still holds the vault, and the top floor chapel. The roof holds both the classic Divine Lorraine sign, and a magnificent view of the city. To enter, walk east on Fairmount until you find a chain link gate, the east end is unhinged, slide through. Walk up to the front plywood door on the building, it is open. Be very careful of being seen, the building is a well known spot and police will come if they have a reason to. Also, the roof is no flat and will not be enjoyed by those afraid of heights.

properties.name: Henry Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga W. School House Lane and henry Avenue Philadelphia, PAOne of the Philadelphia\'s most famous bridges, this early and massive project stretches across the Wissahickon Valley. The interior is enormous and has exquisite rolling arches the whole way across. To Enter, walk west on Henry Avenue until your on top of the bridge, look for manhole covers on the top. Pull the cover off and climb down the ladder into the bridge.

properties.name: Indiana 1700
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga 1700 W. Indiana Avenue Philadelphia, PA A relatively plain former industrial building, on the smaller side. The first floor contains several rooms, while the second remains completely open. It is unclear as to what the building was used for. To enter, walk in through the front door located on the east wall of the building. Watch for minor structural damage, and aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Indiana Military Supply
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga W. Indiana Avenue and N. 20th Street Philadelphia, PAThis enormous factory was at one time manufacturing military equipment, most notably gas masks. On the way in take a look in the ten foot tall piles of discarded equipment. The building itself is divided into two sections, one with a victorian open loft, the other acting as the factory. The second floor houses the textile mill, and the rooftop has a spectacular view as well as an interesting design. To enter, walk north on 20th about a half block until you come to a chain link fence, go under it. Then walk into the building ahead of you that has had the wall and roof partially torn down. Be careful of squatters, and structural damage. Flashlights required.

properties.name: Indiana Warehouse
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga W. Indiana Avenue and 16th street philadelphia, paWith Ivy growing in through the windows, this building at dusk is a picturesque spot. Though it contains very few objects, the large floor space has a quality all to its own. On the top floor open the metal door on the south wall to discover a whole second half of the building. To enter, walk south on 16th under the train overpass. Once through, walk up the hill onto the train tracks and walk roughly one hundred feet south until you come to the remains of chain link fence. Look for a Metal sheet stuck to the side of the building, go into that and climb through the hole in the wood. Watch for people and cars nearby as well as squatters.

properties.name: Manayunk Canal Facility
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Main Street and Leverington Avenue Philadelphia, PAA largely broken down structure at the beginning of the Manayunk Canal. Red Brick with large equipment left from when still in use, this building gives a beautiful view of the Schuylkill River. To enter, walk west along the Manayunk Canal, until you a red brick building on the other side. Cross the canal on the west side of the building. Legal and safe.

properties.name: Manayunk Train Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Dupont Street and High Street Philadelphia, PAFrom the street this mammoth train bridge looks entirely still in use. However, once on top it is a superb spot to watch over Manayunk and the Schuylkill River. To enter, walk south fifty feet to the grown over train tracks, and then walk east along them until the chain link fence. Find the hole in the fence and walk through. Very safe, just try to stay out of view of cars and people.

properties.name: Mt. Moriah Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga S. 62nd and Kingsessing Avenue Philadelphia, PAA largely abandoned cemetery, famous for once holding Betsy Ross\'s grave. Today, walk on the western side and you will find grave with vines growing all over them, and barely kept paths. Two buildings remain, one of which is abandoned but suffers structural damage and squatters. Walk across Cobbs Creek Parkway and find an entire other half in yeadon. To enter, simple walk in. The site is abandoned but still open to the public. Watch for criminal activity.

properties.name: Ortlieb's Brewhouse
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Poplar Street and AMerican Street Philadelphia, PA USAA Famous Philadelphia brewing company, Ortlieb\'s historic brewhouse is split into three sections, including a non-abandoned bottling facility across the street. To enter, walk half a block south on American Street until you see a chain link fence, hop it. Make sure no cars or people spot you entering. Both abandoned buildings can easily be accessed through stair cases in the bottom. The building ranges in damage, however in the building along Poplar Street, many of the stairs are missing from the stair case. I recommend shimmying up the stairs, because the view from that roof is spectacular.

properties.name: Penn Treaty Power Plant
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Columbia Avenue and N. Beach Street Philadelphia, PASitting on the Delaware river next to the picturesque Penn Treaty Park, this abandoned power plant is one of a kind. Still relatively in tact, the building has numerous sections each with their own purpose and interest. The roof has a spectacular view of the city. To enter walk through Penn Treaty park along the north edge. Hop the fence whenever possible, but it is easiest in the eastern corner. Then walk through the second fence heading north. Look for an open window on the east face of the building. Best to go at night, the Power Plant is very visible in daylight. Also, the building is not entirely abandoned and still has lights on in the front. Be careful to stay within the abandoned section and watch the minor structural damage on the roof and aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Philadelphia Engineering Company
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga N. Hope Street and Girard Avenue Philadelphia, PA USAFormerly the factory for Philadelphia Engineering Company, this site was used in the manufacturing of Pesticides and much of the equipment, including labels and canisters, remains. To enter, walk south on hope street about a half block until you see a blue tarp, look for a hole in the tarp and enter. Make sure no cars or people spot you going in. The interior is severely damaged, once on the second floor use extreme caution in where you walk.

properties.name: Reading Trestle
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga N. 12th Street and Noble Street Philadelphia, PA USAAn elevated set of train tracks formerly operated by Reading Railroad, best known for it\'s square on the monopoly board. Today, the Trestle remains fiercely overgrown, but still an interesting view of the post industrial Callowhill section of Philadelphia. To enter, walk half a block west on Noble Street until you see where the Trestle touches the ground. Walk up the Trestle until you hit a chain link fence, climb over. The Trestle eventually would have lead to Reading terminal, but today only stretches as far south as Vine Street. If walked North it leads to both an abandoned train station (see Spring Garden Station (Reading Line) for more information) and into live train lines operated by Amtrak. You are very visible when on the Trestle so try to not be seen, and between the fence and when the Trestle touches down is a beautiful hidden park.

properties.name: Richmond Coal Pier
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga N. Beach Stret and E. Cumberland Street Philadelphia, PA USALocated on the Delaware River, this beautiful, sloping pier contains two sections each with two floors and numerous rooms. Enter through the road, and follow the path. The pier is easily accessed and rarely watched by police or security. However, it is frequented by people playing airsoft, paintball, or dirt biking. In addition, do not go at night, it has been the site of numerous attacks and murders.

properties.name: Richmond Power Plant
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Lewis Street and Delaware Street Philadelphia PA USAClosed in 1985, this historic Power Plant was the site of the Prison in 12 Monkeys. Today it remains an isolated, and heavily secured location, trafficked largely by scrappers and the police. The entry is through the park located to the north of the plant, walk down the path until the trail leads you to a fence with a hole in it. Once in, make sure to stay clear of security officers, cars, and the lit tower. Best to go after 5 pm. Walk towards the main building, walk along the east side, skip the first door, go into the second, climb through the hole in there. Flashlights must be used, the interior is especially dark in spots.

properties.name: Shawmont Pumping Facility
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Shawmont Avenue and Nixon Street Philadelphia, PAAn enormous water facility located along the Schuylkill River. Mostly, empty though a few interesting pieces remain inside the building as well as the building next door. To enter, walk east along the toe path until you see the two large buildings. It\'s both legal and safe. Flashlights are necessary for the building next to the water facility.

properties.name: Spring Garden School
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga N. 12th Street and Parrish Street Philadelphia, PA USAUsed in the 1970s as an Afro-Centric elementary school, Spring Garden School still has textbooks and other resources from when it was still in use. To enter, go to the east side of the building between the school and the annexed library. Climb through the window there. Do not go in large groups, and move quickly so as not to gain attention. The first floor is entirely dark and requires a flashlight. The building is in good condition, though numerous signs of people living there. Police will enter if they believe people are in the school.

properties.name: Spring Garden Station (Reading Line)
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Green Street and Spring Garden Street Philadelphia, PA USAA former Train Station for the Reading Line, this elevated set of tracks and station is quite overgrown. To enter, follow the Reading Trestle north, see Reading Tresstle for access to that. When at the Station and before it you are completely visible to the street, be careful to not be seen. At the station several tents are set up by people living there, be careful around them. The station can only be accessed by climbing up onto platform roof.

properties.name: Spring Garden Station (Ridge Spur)
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Ridge Avenue and Spring Garden Street Philadelphia, PA USAA former stop on the Ridge Spur on the Broad Street line subway, this abandoned station is underneath Ridge Avenue. Still lit, the station is completely painted in graffiti and has much of the original equipment inside. To enter, walk half a block southeast on Ridge Avenue. Notice as you walk that there are grates on the sidewalk. Once you see one that has nothing holding it down, pick it up. This usually requires between two and three people, and is a very physical job. After the grate is off, climb through the ventilation shaft and drop down into the station. Be warned, getting out is harder than getting in. It is best to bring a stool with you, and make sure all members of your group are capable of pulling themselves out. Also, trains still run through the station, go on off peak hours.

properties.name: The Coffee House
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Front Street and Girard Street Philadelphia PA USAThough it is not clear what the exact purpose was of this building prior to abandonment, the large painted coffee mural on the side has given it it\'s name of the Coffee House. To enter, walk south about a half block on Front Street. You will find two doors on the front of the building, both are unlocked, let yourself in, however do not be seen by any cars or people passing by. The interior, is dark and requires a flashlight, it also is unstable in spots, so watch your step.

properties.name: Unique Industries
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Richmond Avenue and Frankford Avenue Philadelphia, PAFormerly the factory of Unique Industries, this oddly constructed building was owned by Everett Novak, a famous horse Jockey who then manufactured party supplies and owned the rights to numerous cartoon characters including Batman and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. The building looks small from the outside due to it\'s location on a number of crossing roads, however, the interior is enormous with varying styles of architecture and purpose. To enter walk south of Richmond until you spot a door that has been bended out, open the door and walk in. Watch for extreme structural damage in spots as well as possible aggressive squatters.

properties.name: Vine Street Textile Factory
properties.description: Posted by Bigchimichonga Wood Street and N. 12th Street Philadelphia, PA 19104A well known abandoned textile factory in the heart of Philadelphia. Though at one time filled with old materials from when the building was in operation, it has since been cleaned out and houses empty floors painted with graffiti. The roof is beautiful and has a spectacular view of the Philadelphia Skyline. To enter, walk around to the south side of the building. Find the opening in the chain link fence and walk to where there is an open window, go in. Make sure not to be seen by cars or people. The Building has been known to have several squatters, but none have proved aggressive.
